questions.question_text: Which two are true about Conditional Compilation in PL/SQL using $IF, $ELSE, $END, and $ERROR? (Choose two.)

choices.B: PL/SQL code can be compiled and executed based on different versions of Oracle.
choices.C: It is newer syntax that works the same way as 'IF , ELSEIF , ELSE, and END IF'.
choices.D: Conditional compilation is disabled by default.
choices.E: The PL/SQL compiler can conditionally include selected parts of a program.
choices.A: PL/SQL code can be compiled and executed based on different versions of the operating system.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: DE
It is D, E
It`s DE

D & E are always right.
A is only right for positional parameters, not for named ones.
B is only right for positional parameters and those parameters distinguish in their types

it is D and E

questions.question_text: Which two are true about named notations in a PL/SQL subprogram? (Choose two.)

choices.D: The subprogram invocations must be changed when the formal parameter list acquires new required parameters.
choices.A: The actual parameters must be specified in the same order as the formal parameters are declared.
choices.E: Any optional parameters can be omitted in the invocation call.
choices.C: Only trailing optional parameters can be omitted in the invocation call.
choices.B: Specifying actual parameters in the wrong order results in the subprogram terminating with an exception.

Selected Answer: EF
he two valid lines are:

Line 2: salary$ VARCHAR2 (10) NOT NULL := '9000S';
Line 3: v_num1, v_num2 NUMBER;
Hereâ€™s why:

Line 2 is valid because salary$ is a valid identifier, and the VARCHAR2 data type is correctly declared with a length and a NOT NULL constraint.
Line 3 is valid because it correctly declares two variables of the NUMBER data type.
The other lines have issues:

Line 4: The syntax is incorrect. It should be v_job VARCHAR2(20);.
Line 5: avg is a reserved keyword in SQL and cannot be used as an identifier.
Line 6: SIMPLE INTEGER is not a valid data type in PL/SQL.
Line 7: #sno is not a valid identifier because it contains a special character (#).

Selected Answer: AB
why line 6th is wrong?

Selected Answer: CF
A: Incorrect because avg is a reserved word.
B: Incorrect because a number must be specified for the data type.
C: Correct.
D: Incorrect because the variable name comes after the data type, which is invalid.
E: Incorrect because two variables cannot be defined on a single line.
F: Correct because # is a valid character for variable names.
